update.description:
This is the scoring plugin for the navigation challenge task.

* The plugin loads a description of the course using SDF parameters. The course is delimited by gates. A gate is delimited by a red and green buoy.
* The gate is supposed to be crossed only in one direction.
* If a gate is crossed in the wrong direction, is considered invalid and won’t be “crossable” in the future.
* When a gate is crossed, it will be ignored in the future.
* The plugin also accepts the name of the model that should cross the gates.
* The gates are “dynamic”. This means that if a buoy moves, the new position of the buoy updates the gate. This is on purpose to be better prepared if buoys move in the future because of the wind or waves.

Note that I didn’t consider the time yet. This is on purpose and will be captured in a separate plugin that could be reused among other scoring plugins.

In order to test it:

    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo navigation_task.launch verbose:=true &
    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo usv_joydrive.launch

Then, you can teleoperate the vehicle with the joystick across the gates.
update.title: Scoring plugin for the navigation course

* The plugin loads a description of the course using SDF parameters. The course is delimited by gates. A gate is delimited by a red and green buoy.

* When a gate is crossed, it will be ignored in the future.
* The plugin also accepts the name of the model that should cross the gates.

pull_request.title: Scoring plugin for the navigation course

pullrequest.title: Scoring plugin for the navigation course

content.raw:
Very elegant.   The use of the vectors and frames is very efficient -  who says you don’t use math in real life!

The gate definition syntax has one ‘red’ and one ‘green’ mark - implicitly defining the correct direction of the gate is to pass with the red to the right of the vessel \(where right is defined by the direction of motion, not the vessel coordinates\).  Perhaps an alternative:

* Could rename the gate tags to none color specific terms - perhaps ‘right’ and ‘left’.  Then the vessel should pass through the gate with the markers on the defined right and left sides, independent of color.  Could be more generally useful?

Definitely a detail, but the invalidation message “\[Msg\] Went backward through gate. Invalidated!” confused me at first.  It doesn’t matter if the vessel transits the gate forwards \(bow first\) or backwards \(stern first\), only the direction of travel.  This is a point we’ll need to be clear on with the instructions.  Perhaps, “transited the gate in the wrong direction” is better?

Otherwise, very nicely done.
content.html:
Very elegant. The use of the vectors and frames is very efficient - who says you don’t use math in real life!

The gate definition syntax has one ‘red’ and one ‘green’ mark - implicitly defining the correct direction of the gate is to pass with the red to the right of the vessel (where right is defined by the direction of motion, not the vessel coordinates). Perhaps an alternative:

  • Could rename the gate tags to none color specific terms - perhaps ‘right’ and ‘left’. Then the vessel should pass through the gate with the markers on the defined right and left sides, independent of color. Could be more generally useful?

Definitely a detail, but the invalidation message “[Msg] Went backward through gate. Invalidated!” confused me at first. It doesn’t matter if the vessel transits the gate forwards (bow first) or backwards (stern first), only the direction of travel. This is a point we’ll need to be clear on with the instructions. Perhaps, “transited the gate in the wrong direction” is better?

Otherwise, very nicely done.

pull_request.title: Scoring plugin for the navigation course

update.description:
This is the scoring plugin for the navigation challenge task.

* The plugin loads a description of the course using SDF parameters. The course is delimited by gates. A gate is delimited by a red and green buoy.
* The gate is supposed to be crossed only in one direction.
* If a gate is crossed in the wrong direction, is considered invalid and won’t be “crossable” in the future.
* When a gate is crossed, it will be ignored in the future.
* The plugin also accepts the name of the model that should cross the gates.
* The gates are “dynamic”. This means that if a buoy moves, the new position of the buoy updates the gate. This is on purpose to be better prepared if buoys move in the future because of the wind or waves.

Note that I didn’t consider the time yet. This is on purpose and will be captured in a separate plugin that could be reused among other scoring plugins.

In order to test it:

    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo navigation_task.launch verbose:=true &
    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo usv_joydrive.launch

Then, you can teleoperate the vehicle with the joystick across the gates.

update.description:
This is the scoring plugin for the navigation challenge task.

* The plugin loads a description of the course using SDF parameters. The course is delimited by gates. A gate is delimited by a red and green buoy.
* The gate is supposed to be crossed only in one direction.
* If a gate is crossed in the wrong direction, is considered invalid and won’t be “crossable” in the future.
* When a gate is crossed, it will be ignored in the future.
* The plugin also accepts the name of the model that should cross the gates.
* The gates are “dynamic”. This means that if a buoy moves, the new positions of the buoys are the “new” gate. This is on purpose to be better prepared if buoys move in the future because of the wind or waves.

Note that I didn’t consider the time yet. This is on purpose and will be captured in a separate plugin that could be reused among other scoring plugins.

In order to test it:

    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo navigation_task.launch verbose:=true &
    roslaunch vmrc_gazebo usv_joydrive.launch

Then, you can teleoperate the vehicle with the joystick across the gates.
